questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with alopecia to a dermatology clinic. She also has pain in the joints for the past 6 months for which she is on NSAIDS. However, there is no deformity. She has no hematuria or dysuria. Urine analysis reveals 3+ proteinuria with granular cast. ANA by ELISA was positive. RA factor was negative. What is the most likely diagnosis:
Which of the following have been included in the immunological criteria for SLE (SLICC) Except:
All of the following are known to cause drug induced Lupus except:

A 44-year-old lady presents to the clinic with shortening of the digits in her hands. She has an history of pallor of extremities followed by pain and cyanosison exposure to cold during her adolescence. 6months back she had noticed puffiness of her fingers and face. ANA was positive with Nucleolar pattern of immunofluorescence. What is the likely diagnosis.

A 22-year female diagnosed as a case of SLE is on immunosuppression since the last 8 months. She is brought to the emergency department in altered sensorium with h/o convulsion. Which is/are the antibody associated with increased risk of above manifestation EXCEPT:
Systemic sclerosis is characterized by following cardinal pathophysiological processes EXCEPT:
The most common cause of death in systemic sclerosis is:
The most common cause of late mortality in a patient of SLE is:
Suspected microorganism in etio- pathogenesis of systemic sclerosis is
Which manifestation is more common in limited systemic sclerosis as compared with diffuse Ssc?
A 42-year-old woman presents with retrosternal discomfort. She was diagnosed with systemic sclerosis one year back. Which of the following statements is true about systemic sclerosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Microstomia is only seen in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

options.label: B
options.text: Skin involvement is restricted to face, hands (distal to elbow) in limited systemic sclerosis

options.label: D
options.text: Raynaud’s occurs due to skin sclerosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Skin involvement is restricted to face, hands (distal to elbow) in limited systemic sclerosis

questions.text: All of the following about Diffuse SSc are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: Raynaud’s phenomenon is seen years before skin changes

questions.text: Secondary Sicca syndrome is associated with all except:
The following statements are true regarding Sjogren’s syndrome EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Primary Sjogren’s is associated with increased risk of systemic manifestations

options.label: B
options.text: secondary Sjogren’s has increased risk of lymphoma

options.label: C
options.text: Elderly onset of disease has poorer prognosis

options.label: D
options.text: High SSA antibody titers is associated with increased risk of lymphoma

questions.correct_answer: B. secondary Sjogren’s has increased risk of lymphoma

questions.text: A middle-aged female presented with polyarthritis, oral ulcers and dryness of eyes. She is found to have elevated RF, and ANA levels. Anti-U1RNP is positive. What is the diagnosis:

The following statements about the skin lesion shown in picture are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: This is seen in SLE patient

questions.text: Which of thefollowing statements about Systemic sclerosis istrue EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Bilateral skin thickenening is the hallmark of the disease

options.label: B
options.text: In established SSc, Mask-like face” with loss of wrinkles can appear.

options.label: C
options.text: Nailbed capilloroscopycan reveal distorted nailbed capillary with micro-hemorrhages

options.label: D
options.text: Nailbed capillaroscopy cannot differentiate between primary and secondary Raynaud’s phenomenon.

questions.correct_answer: D. Nailbed capillaroscopy cannot differentiate between primary and secondary Raynaud’s phenomenon.

questions.text: The most common neurological manifestation in SLE is
The following findings are associated with increased fetal loss during pregnancy in a SLE patient except:
Sarilumab acts by one of the following mechanisms:

A 36-year-old woman presents to the Rheumatology clinic with 2-month history of stiff joints and wrists. She reports that the pain is especially worse for the first few hours of the morning and is affecting her work as a dentist. On examination, the wrists, MCP and PIP joints are warm and swollen. Squeeze test is positive. Which of the following investigations is most specific for confirming the diagnosis:

A 50-year-old female recently diagnosed as a case of rheumatoid arthritis is referred to the rheumatology clinic for ongoing pain in her hands and feet. Which joints are usually spared at the onset of RA?

A 55 years old man presents to you with a 2-week history of pain in his hands. The pain is particularly bad in his right hand. On examination, brown discoloration of his nails with onycholysis is noted and the Distal interphalangeal joints are swollen and tender. What is the most likely diagnosis:

A 76 year old man presents to emergency department with pain in his knees. He describes the pain as been worse at evening and after exertion. On examination, Heber dens nodules are palpable at the DIP. X-ray shows reduction in joint space, subchondral sclerosis and osteophyte formation. What is the most appropriate treatment.

A 32-year-old man presents to emergency with a 1-day history of pain in the right knee joint. He also mentions that he has had a fever and is feeling unwell. On examination, the right knee is swollen, warm and extremely painful on movement. What is the most appropriate step in management:

options.label: C
options.text: Aspiration of the joint and blood cultures

questions.correct_answer: C. Aspiration of the joint and blood cultures

questions.text: 30-year-old female presents with 1-week history of both knee joints. The pain started with the right knee and involved the left in within a couple of days. Further history reveals that she had history for burning micturition 3 weeks back. Urine culture done twice were sterile. What is your diagnosis and probable causative organism.

A 74-year-old female presented with sudden onset pain and swelling in the left knee. On examination she is afebrile. X-ray shows chondrocalcinosis. Microscopic analysis of the synovial fluid is most likely to show:

options.label: C
options.text: Rhomboidal, weakly positive refringent crystals under polarising microscopy

options.label: D
options.text: Needle shaped, strongly negative birefringent crystals under polarising microscopy

questions.correct_answer: C. Rhomboidal, weakly positive refringent crystals under polarising microscopy

questions.text: HLA B27 is usually detected in the. following conditions, except:
All of the statements about Rheumatoid factor in rheumatoid arthritis are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Titers of RA factor is associated with bad prognosis

options.label: B
options.text: It is an IgG type of antibody

options.label: C
options.text: It is themost common inrheumatoid arthritis

options.label: D
options.text: It is non-specific for the diagnosis of RA

questions.correct_answer: B. It is an IgG type of antibody

questions.text: A 27-year-old male had burning micturition and urethral discharge. After 4 weeks he developed joint pains involving both the knees and ankles, redness of the eye and skin lesion, The most probable skin lesion is:
Which of the following disease is associated with the HLA B27 subtype?
All the following statements about Gouty arthritis are true except:

options.label: A
options.text: 90% caused by overproduction of Uric acid

options.label: B
options.text: Uric acid levels maybe normal at the time of acute attack

options.label: C
options.text: Men more likely affected than Females

options.label: D
options.text: Definitive diagnosis requires synovial fluid aspirate

questions.correct_answer: A. 90% caused by overproduction of Uric acid

questions.text: A 53-year Male comes with sudden onset severe pain in first metatarsophalangeal joint. He is a K/C/O gout. His laboratory investigations reveal HB – 9.8, Uric Acid – 11.2 and Creatinine -3.4mg/dl. What is the most appropriate treatment
Feature of axial spondyloarthritis include all except

A 30- year old male patient presents with complaints of weakness in right upper and both lower limbs for last 4 months. He developed digital infarcts involving 2nd and 3rd fingers on right side and 5th finger on left side; On examination, at was 160/140 mm Hg, all peripheral pulses were palpable and there was asymmetrical neuropathy. Investigations showed Hb-12 gm. TLC­12000 cumm, platelets 4,30,000, ESR-49mm. Urine examination showed proteinuria and RBC 10-15/hpfwith no casts. which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most common cause of cardiac death in children due to acquired heart disease is:
questions.correct_answer: B. Mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome (Kawasaki disease)

questions.text: Characteristic of Anaphylactoid purpura is:

A 20-year -old woman presents with bilateral conductive deafness, palpable purpura on thelegs and hemoptysis. Radiograph of the chest shows a thin-walled cavity in left lower zone. Investigation, reveal total leukocyte count 12,000/mm3. cell casts in the urine and serum creatinine 3mg/dl. What is the most probable diagnosis?

An 18-yr-old girl presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss and post prandial abdominal pain. On examination, her BP was 160/100mm of Hg. USG of the Abdomen was inconclusive. Antinuclear antibodies and anti-endomysial antibody were negative. The most likely diagnosis is:

Which one of the following auto-antibodies is most specific for Wegener’s granulomatosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Antidouble stranded DNA antibody (anti ds DNA)
